revision.text:
[[File:Signature of Gabriel de Vallseca (1447).jpg|thumb|250px|Signature of Gabriel de Vallseca from 1447 portolan chart]] '''Gabriel de Vallseca''', also referred to as '''Gabriel de Valseca''' and '''Gabriel de Valsequa''' and '''Gabriel de Vallsecha''' (before 1408 - after 1467) was a [[Catalan people|Catalan]] [[cartographer]] of Jewish descent connected to the [[Majorcan cartographic school]]. His most notable map is the portolan of 1439, containing the first depiction of the recently discovered [[Azores]] islands.
== Life == Gabriel de Vallseca was born in [[Barcelona]] to a family of Jewish [[converso]]s. He is sometimes said to be the son of Haym ibn Risch (of the Cresques family), who, upon conversion, took the name Juan de Vallsecha.<ref>Novinsky (1990:68)</ref> Alternatively, he had [[Majorcan]] relatives through his mother or his wife.<ref>Ginard Bujosa, p.59. Also ''Encycl. of Majorca''.</ref>
By 1433, Vallseca had left Barcelona and was living in [[Palma, Majorca]], where he soon made a name for himself as a master cartographer, instrument-maker and merchant. He lived in the parish of Santa Creu, in the marine and commercial district of the city. He married Floreta Miró and had two sons, Francesc and Joan, both of whom later had run-ins with the [[Spanish Inquisition]] for "judaizing", which suggests their father Gabriel may also have been a [[Crypto-Judaism|crypto-Jew]]. Vallseca wrote out his last will in the city of Majorca in 1467 and died shortly after.<ref>Families de jueus conversos mallorquines ennoblides a Sicília: Els Tarongí i els Vallseca. P de Muntaner, Revista Lluc, març-abril 2006, pàg. 21 i següents {{ISSN|0211-092X}}</ref>
== Works == [[File:Portolan chart of Gabriel de Vallseca (1447).jpg|thumb|250px|1447 portolan chart of Gabriel de Vallseca (BNF, Paris).]] There are three existing [[portolan chart]]s signed by Gabriel Vallseca
* Map of 1439, at the [[Maritime Museum of Barcelona|Museu Marítim de Barcelona]] (inv. 3236) - partial mappa mundi * Map of 1447, at the [[Bibliothèque nationale de France]] (Rés. Ge. C4607) - Mediterranean only * Map of 1449 at the [[Archivio di Stato di Firenze]] (CN 22) - Mediterranean only
There are also two anonymous maps attributed to him:
* Undated map (est.1440) at [[National Central Library (Florence)|Biblioteca Nazionale Centrale di Firenze]] (portolà 16) - partial mappa mundi * Undated map (est. 1447) at [[Bibliothèque nationale de France]] (Rés. Ge. D 3005) - fragments of the eastern Mediterranean
Although his style conforms to the traditional [[Majorcan cartographic school]], Vallseca incorporated some more contemporary innovations in cartography from Italy, Portugal and elsewhere, most notably from [[Francesco Beccario]] (e.g. the homogenization of the scale between the Mediterranean and Atlantic). Gabriel de Vallseca's charts retain some signature Majorcan decorative motifs, such as the [[wind rose]], miniature humans,animals and plants, the [[Atlas Mountains]] shaped as a [[palm (plant)|palm]], [[the Alps]] as a chicken's foot, [[Bohemia]] as a horseshoe, the [[Danube]] as a chain, the [[Tagus]] as a shepherd's crook, the [[Red Sea]] colored red, and scattered notes and labels in the [[Catalan language]].
=== 1439 Map ===
[[File:Gabriel Vallseca. Museo Marítimo, Barcelona.1439.jpg|thumb|350px|1439 portolan chart of Gabriel de Vallseca (Museu Maritim, Barcelona)]] Vallseca's most famous map is the portolan of 1439, particularly for incorporating the very recent discoveries of the captains of the Portuguese Prince [[Henry the Navigator]]. Its depiction of the Atlantic Ocean stretches from [[Scandinavia]] down to the [[Rio de Oro]] and including the Atlantic islands of the [[Azores]], [[Madeira]] and [[Canary Islands|Canaries]], as well as the imaginary islands of [[Thule]], [[Brazil (mythical island)|Brazil]] and [[Isle of Mam|Mam]].
The most notable is the depiction of the islands of the Azores (officially discovered in 1431 by Henry's captain [[Gonçalo Velho|Gonçalo Velho Cabral]]), which although incorrectly spaced, are accurately depicted for the first time as strung out from southeast to northwest.
The 1439 map is signed ''Gabriell de Valsequa la feta en Malorcha, any MCCC.XXX.VIIII''. According to a marginal note on the reverse side, this map was once owned by [[Amerigo Vespucci]], who paid 80 gold [[ducat]]s for it. (''Questa ampia pella di geographia fue pagata da Amerigo Vespuci - LXXX ducati di oro di marco''). It is conjectured Vespucci probably acquired it in [[Florence]] in the 1480s, and that he might have even have taken it on his 1497-1504 voyages to the [[New World]].
The 1439 Vallseca map was acquired in Florence by the Cardinal [[Antonio Despuig y Dameto]] sometime before 1785, and subsequently came into the possession of his heirs, the Majorcan Counts of Montenegro. The map suffered an accident in the winter of 1838/39, when the Count of Montenegro was in the process of showing it to his visitors, [[Frédéric Chopin]] and [[George Sand]]. A carelessly-placed inkwell tipped onto the map, causing irreparable blots and marring the legibility of some of the labels on the western part of the map.<ref>The accident is related in George Sand's ''Un hiver à Majorque'' (1842, 1869 ed.: [https://books.google.com/books?id=0YgNAAAAQAAJ&pg=PA63#v=onepage&q&f=false p.63]).</ref>
Most notably, the inkwell accident damaged Vallseca's crucial note pertaining to the discovery of the [[Azores]]. The current note reads as follows:
{{quote|''Aquestes isles foram trobades p diego de ??? pelot del rey de portugal an lay MCCCCXX?II'' (Transl. "These islands were found by Diego de ? pilot of the King of Portugal in the year 14??")}}
The surname and part of the date are smudged. The earliest reading we have of this portion of the map is by a Majorcan named Pasqual in 1789 who jotted the surname down as "Guullen".<ref>Mees, [https://books.google.com/books?id=zZEDAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA70#v=onepage&q&f=false p.70]</ref> It has since been read as Diego de Senill<ref>e.g. Santarem, p.390.</ref> ('the Old' - a hopeful reading in the direction of [[Gonçalo Velho]]) and de Sevill<ref>e.g. d'Avenzac [https://books.google.com/books?id=fYJAAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA31#v=onepage&q&f=false p.31], Mees,p.71; Beazley, p.lxxxvi</ref> or de Sunis,<ref>Proposed by José Gomez Imaz, director of the reproduction for the 1892 centenary (as quoted in Mees, p.71)</ref> Survis, Sinus, Simis, Sines. The date has been alternatively interpreted MCCCCXX'''V'''II (1427) or MCCCCXX'''X'''II (1432)<ref>1432 is preferred by Santarem, again allowing for Gonçalo Velho's discovery of 1431</ref> or MCCCCXX'''XV'''II (1437). In 1943, historian Damião Peres proposed [[Diogo de Silves]] and the date as 1427, which is now commonly cited in Portuguese sources.<ref>Damião Peres (1943) ''História dos Descobrimentos Portugueses'', p.83.</ref>
Vallseca names eight or nine islands of the Azores, which have been hard to read because of the ink accident. One 1841 reading (by the Visconde de Santarem) identifies the names of the eight islands as ''Ylla de Osels'' (Ucello, [[Santa Maria Island (Azores)|Santa Maria]]), ''Ylla de Frydols'' ([[São Miguel Island|São Miguel]]), ''Ylla de l'Inferno'' ([[Terceira Island|Terceira]]), ''Guatrilla'' ([[São Jorge Island|São Jorge]]), ''de Sperta'' ([[Pico Island|Pico]]), ''Ylla de ....?'' (erased, [[Faial Island|Faial]]?) and (although not yet officially discovered) the more westerly ''Ylla de Corp-Marinos'' ([[Corvo Island|Corvo]]) and ''Conigi'' ([[Flores Island (Azores)|Flores]]) (these last two would only be officially discovered by [[Diogo de Teive]] in 1452; Vallseca apparently lifted these last two from the [[Catalan Atlas]] of 1375).<ref>Visconde de Santarem, note in 1841 edition of Zurara's ''Chronica'', [https://books.google.com/books?id=Nr4NAAAAQAAJ&pg=PA390#v=onepage&q&f=false p.390]. The correspondence with the modern Azores islands is due to Beazley's edition of the ''Chronicle'' [https://books.google.com/books?id=zboUfMcP1xcC&pg=PR86#v=onepage&q&f=false p. lxxxvi]</ref> Other readings decipher "deserta" (rather than de Sperta), "jlla bela" (instead of Guatrilla), ''illa aucells'' or ''jlha aurolls'' (instead of Osels/Uccello), ''faucols'' (instead of Frydols) and ''raio marnos'' or ''vegis marins'' (instead of Corp-Marinos).<ref>A. Cortesão, 1954: [https://books.google.com/books?id=2PbNS0LHn60C&lpg=PP1&pg=RA1-PA157#v=onepage&q&f=false p.157n]. See also Jordão de Freitas (1937)</ref>
In 1910, the Count of Montenegro put the 1439 map up for sale. It was bought by the Catalan Pere Bosc i Oliver, who proceeded to sell it to the [[Institute of Catalan Studies]], which deposited it at the [[National Library of Catalonia]] in Barcelona in 1917. It was transferred in 1960 to the [[Maritime Museum of Barcelona|Museu Marítim de Barcelona]], where it is currently on display.
There is one reproduction of the map, made in 1892 for an exhibition on the 4th centenary of Columbus in Spain, that is currently in the possession of the [[Naval Museum of Madrid]].

Stat., Florence) </gallery>

Solomon''' ([[Telugu language|Telugu]]: గద్దల సొలమన్ అయ్యగరు) ''(born 28 December 1910; died 6 February 1993)'' was an [[Old Testament]] Scholar and a [[Baptist]] Patriarch hailing from the [[Protestant]] [[Samavesam of Telugu Baptist Churches|Samavesam of Telugu Baptist Churches Society]] ''(an affiliate member of the [[Baptist World Alliance]] and the [[National Council of Churches in India]])'' and led it as its President during the years 1978-1982 overseeing the spiritual affairs of the Church Society whose ecclesiastical jurisdiction comprises the three states of [[Tamil Nadu]], [[Andhra Pradesh]] and [[Telangana]] with 873A. John Prabhakar, ''Preaching Contextually: A Case with Rural Dalits in India'', Notion Press, Chennai, 2016.[https://books.google.com/books?id=d040DQAAQBAJ&lpg=PT34&dq=samavesam%20of%20telugu%20baptist%20churches%20membership&pg=PT33#v=onepage&q=samavesam%20of%20telugu%20baptist%20churches%20membership&f=false] Churches comprising nearly a million members per present statistics. ==Contribution== ===Comparative analysis=== In 1957, Solomon made a comparative analysis of [[suffering]] as viewed in two ancient [[scriptures]], one from the [[Ancient Near East]] and the other from the [[Indian subcontinent]] where he provides the respective literature on [[suffering]] in both the [[scripture]]s, its genesis and outlook and some common insights between the two, particularly on [[Divine retribution|retribution]] (see [[Klaus Koch]] (1955): ''Is there a Doctrine of Retribution in the [[Old Testament]]'').[[Klaus Koch]], ''Is there a Doctrine of Retribution in the Old Testament ?'' in [[James L. Crenshaw]] (Edited), ''Theodicy in the Old Testament'', Fortress Press, Philadelphia, 1983, pp. 57-87.[https://books.google.com/books/about/Theodicy_in_the_Old_Testament.html?id=RM_YAAAAMAAJ&redir_esc=y] Solomon highlights the example of [[Job (biblical figure)]] where the sufferer endures it with the thought of a glimmer of hope some day or the other reposing unflinching trust in [[God]]. [[Old Testament]] Scholars down the line have drawn parallelsS. Prabhakara Rao and M. Prakasa Reddy, ''Job and His Satan - Parallels in Indian Scripture'' in ''[[Zeitschrift für die Alttestamentliche Wissenschaft]]'', Volume 91, Issue 3, Berlin, 1979. on [[Job (biblical figure)|Prophet Job]] and [[Harishchandra|Raja Satya Harishchandra]] providing scholarly insights into the problem of [[suffering]] endured by these two legendsMadanu Francis, ''Why the Innocent Suffer: [[Job (biblical figure)|Job]] and [[Harishchandra]]: Biblical and Puranic Expression'', [[St. John's Regional Seminary]], [[Hyderabad]], 1998. and how they overcame it for a cause. A chronological analysis of the comparative literature on the problem of [[suffering]] in addition to the one by Solomon, reveals that [[John Bowker (theologian)|John Bowker]] came out with ''Problems of Suffering in Religions of the World'' in 1970 where [[suffering]] as viewed by the diverse religions of the world has been presented.[[John Bowker (theologian)|John Bowker]], ''Problems of Suffering in Religions of the World'', [[Cambridge University Press]], Cambridge, 1970.[https://books.google.com/books?id=W7IcQL1JBvAC&lpg=PP1&dq=suffering%20in%20world%20religions&pg=PP5#v=onepage&q=chandra&f=false] Later, in 1979, the [[Pune]]-based inquisitive [[Chemical engineer]]s of the [[National Chemical Laboratory]] namely S. Prabhakara RaoS. Prabhakara Rao, S. Ponarathnam and S. L. Kapur, ''The applicability of Kelen-Tudos method for the evaluation of monomer activity ratios in high conversions copolymerization'', in ''Report'', National Chemical Laboratory of India, Pune, 1976, p.110. [https://books.google.com/books?id=hIFFAQAAIAAJ&dq=prabhakara+rao+national+chemical+laboratory&focus=searchwithinvolume&q=rao] and M. Prakasa ReddyM. Prakasa Reddy and James E. Sturm, ''Decomposition of ethane in radiolysis and in glow discharges: Temperature and Pressure Effects'' in ''Bulletin de la Société chimique'', Volume 40, p.237 ff., 1975.[https://books.google.com/books?id=OapQAQAAMAAJ&q=reddy+Decomposition+of+ethane+in+radiolysis+and+in+glow+discharges&dq=reddy+Decomposition+of+ethane+in+radiolysis+and+in+glow+discharges&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjkpKKPrfvSAhXBuI8KHTc1BbkQ6AEIGTAA] came out with ''Job and His Satan - Parallels in Indian Scripture'' which was published in the [[Germany|German]] [[Old Testament]] scholarly journal, ''[[ZAW]]''. A couple of years' later, [[David J. A. Clines]] came out with a research paper entitled ''In Search of the Indian Job'' where he provides a century of scholarly research on [[Job (biblical figure)|Job]] and [[Harishchandra|Raja Satya Harishchandra]] that appeared in the ''[[Vetus Testamentum]]''.[[David J. A. Clines|D. J. A. Clines]], ''In Search of the Indian Job'' in ''[[Vetus Testamentum]]'', Volume 33, Fasc. 4, October 1983, pp. 398-418. [https://www.jstor.org/stable/1517973] Later in 1998, a Scholar at the St. Peter's Pontifical Seminary, [[Bangalore]] studying under [[Anthony Raymond Ceresko]] and [[Gnana Robinson]] researched specifically on [[Job (biblical figure)|Job]] and [[Harishchandra]] focusing on the problem of suffering. Solomon's research brought out the many facets of [[suffering]] where his scholarship is profoundly visible as he sheaves through the views on suffering in the [[Old Testament]] as he quotes from the [[Pentateuch]] and the other books of the [[Old Testament]] with a comprehensive bibliography but the conclusions that he drew are an eye opener for those viewing [[suffering]] as a reason of our own follies. In the final analysis, Solomon looks into the possibilities of a more [[humane]] understanding of [[suffering]] overcoming [[Dogma]] and providing for [[repentance]] or rather an opportunity to set right the past and move forward. Solomon wrote, ''The solution of the problem of suffering in [[Christianity]] is that God also suffers along with the sufferer and helps him to endure it for His glory.'' Solomon's work could best be understood if one were to look at a 1990G. Babu Rao, ''[[Wisdom tradition]] and the Indian Parallels with special reference to [[Telugu literature]]'' in ''Reflections on Theology Today'', ACTC, Hyderabad, 1990.[http://www.religion-online.org/showarticle.asp?title=3540] work entitled ''[[Wisdom tradition]] and the Indian Parallels with special reference to [[Telugu literature]]'' by the [[Old Testament]] Scholar,G. Babu Rao, ''Content Analysis of Theological Syllabi – [[Old Testament]]'' in ''Religion and Society'', Christian Institute for the Study of Religion and Society, 3 September 1985. [https://books.google.com/books?um=1&q=g.babu+rao+doctoral+studies&btnG=Search+Books] G. Babu Rao, who writes, {{quote| (Adapted) ''Our study of [[Old Testament]] will be more interesting and more constructive if we identify as many parallels as we can in the [[Indian culture]] and literature. The goal of our digging into our cultural heritage and relating it to the biblical traditions is to promote goodwill towards our fellow humans and to work together for the welfare of the people in relation to the nature and to our Creator, in order that all humans may be successful in achieving mastery of life.''}} ===Old Testament teaching=== As an [[Old Testament]] Teacher, Solomon first taught at the Ramayapatnam Baptist Theological Seminary, [[Ramayapatnam]] from 1958B. R. Moses, ''Ramayapatnam Baptist Theological Seminary Centenary Report 1874-1974'', in K. J. W. Jayakumar (Compiled), ''The Lights That Never Quench - Baptist Missionaries'', Self published by the author, Nellore, 2008, pp.107-114. to 1972 during the Principalships of [[The Reverend|The Rev.]] Maurice BlanchardPeter Penner, ''Russians, North Americans, and Telugus: The Mennonite Brethren Mission in [[India]] 1885-1975'', Kindred Productions, Winnipeg, 1997, p.141.[https://books.google.com/books?id=9ZMo4V4Ll8wC&lpg=PA181&ots=zRWBKeu0j9&dq=blanchard%20ramapatnam&pg=PA181#v=onepage&q=blanchard%20ramapatnam&f=false] and [[The Reverend|The Rev.]] [[Louis F. Knoll]]. Subsequently in 1962, the seminary was affiliatedGeorge M. Anathil, ''The Theological Formation of the Clergy in India'', Pontifical Athenaeum, [[Rome]], 1966, p.190. [https://books.google.com/books?id=tAI9AAAAIAAJ&q=ramapatnam+baptist+serampore+1962&dq=ramapatnam+baptist+serampore+1962&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjFp96Tj_jSAhXMvo8KHSxCBikQ6AEIJTAC] to the [[Senate of Serampore College (University)]], India's firstSankar Ray, ''[[The Hindu Business Line]]'', 11 April 2008 ''Almost a century later, the charter was endorsed officially under the Bengal Govt Act IV of 1918. '' Internet, accessed 30 November 2008. [http://www.thehindubusinessline.com/life/2008/04/11/stories/2008041150100400.htm] UniversityThe [[Senate of Serampore College (University)]] is a University within the meaning of Section 2 (f) of the UGC Act, 1956 under which ''a University means a University established or incorporated by or under a Central Act, a Provincial Act or a State Act, and includes any such institution as may, in consultation with the University concerned, be recoginsed by the Commission in accordance with the regulations made in this behalf under this Act.'' The UGC took the opinion that the Senate fell under the purview of Section 2 (f) of the said Act since ''The Serampore College Act, 1918'' was passed by the Government of West Bengal. making the seminary become the first [[Bachelor of Divinity|B.D.]]-level institutionThere have been other seminaries which were affiliated to Serampore but offered only [[Licentiate of Theology|L.Th.]] level courses. See [[Baptist Theological Seminary]], [[Kakinada]]. in [[Andhra Pradesh]] to be affiliated with the University. In the [[seventies]], [[Ecumenism]] brought together the different seminaries in [[Andhra Pradesh]] and [[Telangana]] with the starting of the near-[[ecumenical]] [[Andhra Christian Theological College]] in the year 1964James A. Scherer, ''Mission and Unity in Lutheranism: A Study in Confession and Ecumenicity'', Fortress Press, Philadelphia, 1969, p.234. [https://books.google.com/books?id=7DblAAAAMAAJ&q=1964+andhra+christian+theological+college&dq=1964+andhra+christian+theological+college&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjO3KX8mvvSAhULPY8KHUY-ApIQ6AEIPDAI] by the [[Baptists]] ([[CBCNC]]), the [[Lutherans]] ([[Andhra Evangelical Lutheran Church|AELC]], [[South Andhra Lutheran Church|SALC]]), the [[Methodists]] ([[Methodist Church in India|MCI]]) and the [[Anglicans]], [[Congregationalists]] and the [[Wesleyanism|Wesleyans]] ([[Church of South India|CSI]]). Solomon's Church Society, the [[Samavesam of Telugu Baptist Churches]] was already running a seminary with [[English language|English]] as a medium of instruction with [[Serampore]] affiliation for its [[Bachelor of Divinity|B.D.]] whereas the new near-[[ecumenical]] venture offered [[Licentiate in Theology|L.Th.]] courses in [[Telugu language|Telugu]] as a medium of instruction. However, two years' later, the Ramayapatnam Baptist Theological Seminary through the efforts of both [[The Reverend|The Rev.]] Maurice Blanchard as well as [[The Reverend|The Rev.]] [[Louis F. Knoll]] in 1967,[https://books.google.com/books?id=wsTYAAAAMAAJ&q=1967+ramapatnam+andhra+christian+theological+college&dq=1967+ramapatnam+andhra+christian+theological+college&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwif7ZTylfjSAhVLLI8KHbXmAD4Q6AEIIzAC ''Indian Church History Review,'' Volume 13, 1979, p.81] with the cooperation of the [[Convention of Baptist Churches of Northern Circars]] who sent their learned faculty comprising W. G. Carder''Year Book of the Baptist Convention of Ontario and Quebec, 1970, p.113.[https://books.google.com/books?id=rW3kAAAAMAAJ&dq=canadian+baptist+mission+ramapatnam+baptist&focus=searchwithinvolume&q=ramapatnam] began to function as a separate entity together with the within the campus of the newly-formed near-[[ecumenical]] [[Andhra Christian Theological College]] at its erstwhile location in [[Rajahmundry]], giving an unprecedented impetus to the new near-[[ecumenical]] venture as the inclusion of the [[Ramayapatnam]] Seminary meant higher level theological education as well as [[English language|English]] as the medium of instruction and also the availability of the well-trained faculty of the [[Ramayapatnam]] Seminary comprising Solomon, [[Suppogu Joseph]], [[Louis F. Knoll]], P. Joseph, K. Wilson and others who moved from [[Ramayapatnam]] to [[Rajahmundry]] to take up [[Bachelor of Divinity|B.D.]] classes teaching alongside the faculty of [[Andhra Christian Theological College]] which was then entitled to offer only [[Licentiate in Theology]][https://books.google.com/books?id=677kAAAAMAAJ&q=licentiate+in+theology+rajahmundry&dq=licentiate+in+theology+rajahmundry&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwizy_7bnPjSAhUMso8KHVaXBhEQ6AEIITAC ''Yearbook 1965 of the United Lutheran Church in America'', 1965, p.11] courses. By 1972, [[Louis F. Knoll]] along with [[W. P. Peery]] led the integration of the [[Bachelor of Divinity|B.D.]] section of the [[Ramayapatnam]] Baptist Theological Seminary into the [[Andhra Christian Theological College]] before it moved in 1973 to its present location in [[Secunderabad]]. ==Studies== After general studies at the [[Andhra Evangelical Lutheran Church|AELC]]-[[Andhra Christian College]], [[Guntur]] leading to [[Bachelor of Arts]] in [[Mathematics]] under the [[Andhra University]] in 1934, Solomon took up work at the [[Buckingham and Carnatic Mills]] in [[Chennai]] but a decade later, discerned his avocation towards priesthood and much like the early Church Father, [[Saint Ambrose of Milan]], Solomon relinquished civil work at [[Chennai]] and took to priesthood. ===Graduate=== By 1949,K. M. Hiwale (Compiled), ''Directory of the [[United Theological College, Bangalore|United Theological College]] 1910-1997'', Bangalore, 1997. Past students of the college diploma course, p.24. Solomon enrolled at the Protestant Regional Theologiate - the [[United Theological College, Bangalore]] for spiritual studies during the Principalship of [[Max Hunter Harrison]], the College's first [[Old Testament]] Teacher and studied until 1952 for the three year [[Bachelor of Divinity]] course. Solomon's companions who were studying at the College at varying intervals included, [[D. J. Ambalavanar]], [[N. D. Ananda Rao Samuel]], [[V. C. Samuel]], [[Victor Premasagar]], [[E. C. John]], [[Bobbili Prabhudass]] and others. During the ensuing convocation of the [[Senate of Serampore College (University)]] held in 1953, Solomon was awarded a [[Bachelor of Divinity]] during the Registrarship of [[The Reverend|The Rev.]] W. W. Winfield. ===Postgraduate=== During 1956-1957, Solomon was sent for postgraduate studies to the [[Eastern Baptist Theological Seminary]],[http://www.worldcat.org/title/concept-of-suffering-in-the-bible-and-in-hinduism/oclc/13351098 ''OCLC''] [[King of Prussia, Pennsylvania|King of Prussia]], [[Pennsylvania]] where he specialized in [[Old Testament]] and [[Biblical Hebrew]] language under the guidance of [[Edward R. Dalglish]], Carl H. Morgan,Carl H. Morgan, ''The layperson's introduction to the New Testament'', Judson Press, Valley Forge, 1991.[http://trove.nla.gov.au/work/6449835?selectedversion=NBD7550578] and Walter B. S. Davis.''Supplement to the Evangelical Theological Society Directory, Volume VII, p.36.''.[http://www.etsjets.org/files/JETS-PDFs/7/7-1/BETS_7-1_Miscellaneous%20&%20Back%20Matter.pdf] By 1957, Solomon's research with the title, ''The Concept of Suffering in the Bible and [[Hinduism]]''G. Solomon, ''The Concept of Suffering in the Bible and in Hinduism'', Eastern Baptist Theological Seminary, [[King of Prussia, Pennsylvania|King of Prussia]], 1957. [https://books.google.com/books?id=nwqmNwAACAAJ&dq=gaddala+solomon&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwixhqeykPfSAhXLOo8KHZG5D0kQ6AEIGTAA] was published by the seminary leading to the award of [[Master of Theology]] in [[Old Testament]]. Solomon's research work was translated into [[Telugu language|Telugu]] and published in 1964 with the title, ''Images in Suffering'' ([[Telugu language|Telugu]]: బాధయొక్క భావఛిత్రణము) that also appeared in 1993 in the compilation entitled ''Bibliography of Original Christian Writings in India in Telugu'' published by the [[Board of Theological Education of the Senate of Serampore College]] ([[BTESSC]]).[[Ravela Joseph]], [[Suneel Bhanu]] (Compiled), ''Bibliography of Original Christian Writings in India in Telugu'', published by the Board of Theological Education of the Senate of Serampore, Bangalore, 1993. [https://books.google.com/books?id=3YPgAAAAMAAJ&dq=] Solomon was among the first in [[India]] to have specialized in the [[Old Testament]] in the [[fifties]] with the others being [[K. V. Mathew]], [[Rene Van de Walle]], and [[E. C. John]], all of whom were distinguished members of the Society for Biblical Studies in India.[[Father (title)|Fr.]] Max Gonsalves (Compiled), ''Society for Biblical Studies in India Directory 1998''. ===Specialized studies in Hebrew=== During 1972-1973, Solomon again joined his [[alma mater]], the [[United Theological College, Bangalore]] during the Principalship of the [[Systematic theology|Systematic Theologian]], [[Joshua Russell Chandran]] to study for a [[Biblical Hebrew]] language refresher course studying under the [[Old Testament]] Scholars, [[E. C. John]] and [[G. M. Butterworth]], the former being a direct student of [[Old Testament]]'s Master Specialists, [[Gerhard von Rad]] and [[Claus Westermann]] at the [[University of Heidelberg]], [[Germany]]. Solomon's companions at the College during 1972-1973 included Johanna Rose Ratnavathi, Florence,''Quaint church celebrates 122 years'' in the [[Deccan Herald]], 2 August 2010.[http://www.deccanherald.com/content/85476/quaint-church-celebrates-122-years.html] Nirmala Kumari,Aruna Gnanadason, ''Theology of Humanhood: Women's Perspectives : Report of a National Consultation'', ISPCK/AICCW, Nagpur, 1986, p.154. [https://books.google.com/books?id=S3YLAAAAIAAJ&q=nirmala+vasanth+bangalore&dq=nirmala+vasanth+bangalore&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjbhO-Jmf3SAhULqo8KHdj7Ci8Q6AEIGTAA] Eleanor, [[D. Dhanaraj]], [[John Sadananda]], [[J. W. Gladstone]], [[Sydney Salins]], [[Christopher Asir]], [[P. Surya Prakash]] and others hailing from the graduate section, while [[D. S. Satyaranjan]], [[Nitoy Achumi]], [[Timotheas Hembrom]], G. Babu Rao, [[Basil Rebera]] and [[S. J. Theodore]] hailed from the postgraduate section. ==Ecclesiastical Ministry== ===Pastoral=== ====1951-1957: Tamil Nadu==== Solomon first served as a Pastor[[Ravela Joseph|R. Joseph]], ''A History of the Telugu Baptist Churches ([[American Baptist Mission]]), [[Andhra Christian Theological College]], [[Secunderabad]], 2003, p.61. Cited by James Elisha Taneti in ''Caste, Gender and Christianity in Colonial India''. [https://books.google.com/books?id=W1xAHHzUbNsC&pg=PA91&lpg=PA91&dq=ravela+joseph+baptist&source=bl&ots=cRVg-SCtVA&sig=EcJvca-Q-_F0UVlyG8l73HcBBQo&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CCwQ6AEwA2oVChMI766U3IHsxgIVJySmCh2SEgSG#v=onepage&q=ravela%20joseph%20baptist&f=false] at the Waterbury Memorial Telugu Baptist Church in [[Perambur]] in suburban [[Chennai]] during 1951-1957 till he embarked on an overseas sojourn for his postgraduate studies. ====1977-1986: Telangana==== While teaching at the [[Andhra Christian Theological College]], Solomon was recalled by the [[Samavesam of Telugu Baptist Churches]] in 1977 to take up ministerial duties at the [[Samavesam of Telugu Baptist Churches|STBC]]-[[Centenary Baptist Church, Clock Tower, Secunderabad|Centenary Baptist Church]], [[Secunderabad]] in 1977. Solomon pastored the Church for nearly a decade until 1986 when he voluntarily resigned from the ministerial functions of the Church citing health reasons much like the present [[Pope Benedict XVI]]. ===Teaching=== ====1958-1972: Andhra Pradesh==== When Solomon returned from the [[United States]] in 1958, he took up teaching of the [[Old Testament]]''Foundations: A Baptist Journal of History and Theology'', Volumes 11-12, 1968, pp.318-319. [https://books.google.com/books?id=YV0mAQAAIAAJ&q=gaddala+solomon&dq=gaddala+solomon&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwixhqeykPfSAhXLOo8KHZG5D0kQ6AEIHTAB] at the [[Ramayapatnam]] Baptist Theological Seminary, [[Ramayapatnam]] and later affiliated to the [[Senate of Serampore College (University)]] in 1962. Subsequently, in 1967, the [[Bachelor of Divinity|B.D.]] section of the Seminary moved to [[Rajahmundry]] and was housed within the premises of the newly-founded [[Andhra Christian Theological College]] in [[Rajahmundry]] until it fully integrated into the [[Andhra Christian Theological College]] in 1972 by [[Louis F. Knoll]]''Foundations'', Volume 11, American Baptist Historical Society, 1968. p. 321. [https://books.google.com/books?cd=8&id=ZWnkAAAAMAAJ&dq=] and later shifted to [[Secunderabad]] in 1973. Solomon's students at [[Ramayapatnam]] and [[Rajahmundry]] included the [[Church historian]] [[Ravela Joseph]], the [[New Testament]] Scholar [[Suppogu Joseph]], [[Bishop Emeritus]] [[T. S. Kanaka Prasad]], [[S. E. Krupa Rao]], B. J. Christie Kumar and others. ====1973-1977: Telangana==== In 1973, Solomon moved to the [[Andhra Christian Theological College]] which by then had shifted''Minutes of the Biennial Convention, Issue 7'', Lutheran Church in America, 1974, p.553.[https://books.google.com/books?id=SALkAAAAMAAJ&dq=andhra+christian+theological+college&focus=searchwithinvolume&q=coleman] in its entirety from [[Rajahmundry]] to [[Secunderabad]] and taught [[Old Testament]] and [[Biblical Hebrew]] language to aspirants hailing from the [[Anglican]], [[Baptist]], [[Congregational]], [[Lutheran]], [[Methodist]], [[Pentecostal]], [[Wesleyanism|Wesleyan]] and other small and indigenous Church Societies. Solomon's other teaching colleagues included the [[Cantabrigian]] [[Victor Premasagar]], the [[Wisconsin University]]-Scholar, [[R. R. Sundara Rao]], the [[New Testament]] Scholar, [[Muriel Spurgeon Carder]], the Religions Scholars, [[Eric J. Lott]], [[W. P. Peery]], the [[Systematic theology|Systematic Theologians]], [[Ryder Devapriam]], [[Regunta Yesurathnam|R. Yesurathnam]] and others coinciding with the teaching tenures of Gali Bali, [[John Wijngaards]] and others at the [[St. John's Regional Seminary]], the [[Roman Catholic|Catholic]] Regional Theologiate. By 1977, Solomon had to leave the College as his Church Society recalled him and assigned ministerial duties at the local Church in [[Secunderabad]] and was succeeded by [[The Reverend|The Rev.]] G. Babu Rao,[https://books.google.com/books?id=txUnAQAAIAAJ&q=babu+rao+old+testament&dq=babu+rao+old+testament&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjO76Hvi7nMAhVGYKYKHWBmBLoQ6AEILTAC ''Guide to Indian Periodical Literature'', Volume 23, 1989, p.57] a Teacher''The Story of Serampore and its College'', Council of Serampore College, Serampore (Fourth Edition), 2005, p.92.[https://books.google.com/books?id=3zLPAAAAMAAJ&q=the+story+of+serampore+and+its+college&dq=the+story+of+serampore+and+its+college&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwj3mbuxrPfSAhVKvI8KHUisCCgQ6AEIIzAC] - in - [[Old Testament]] at [[Serampore College]], [[Serampore]]. Among Solomon's students during that period included Alexander John, [[Church of South India|CSI]], T. Punnaiah, [[Samavesam of Telugu Baptist Churches|STBC]], L. Samuel John, [[Andhra Evangelical Lutheran Church|AELC]], D. Vasantha Rao, [[CBCNC]], K. C. Martin, [[Church of South India|CSI]], [[Bishop Emeritus]] [[A. Rajarathnam]], [[Church of South India|CSI]], and others.''1975 Convocation Brochure of the [[Senate of Serampore College (University)]] at [[Serampore College]], [[Serampore]]''. ==Reminisce== Talathoti Punnaiah, who was an aspirant at the [[Ramayapatnam]] Baptist Theological Seminary in [[Ramayapatnam]] during 1969 in his memoir titled ''My Memoir, Ministry and Message'' writes,Talathoti Punnaiah, ''My Memoir, Ministry and Message: (60 years Life Experiences 1950-2010)'', Kakinada, 2010, pp.11-12. {{quote|''A well educated senior Professor and Preacher, well versed in the Bible - he was an Old Testament Professor.''}} ==References== {{Reflist|2}} ==Further reading== * {{cite journal | author=A. John Prabhakar | title=Preaching Contextually: A Case with Rural Dalits in India | year=2016 | volume= | issue= | isbn=978-1-945926-85-3 | url =https://books.google.com/books?id=d040DQAAQBAJ&lpg=PT34&dq=samavesam%20of%20telugu%20baptist%20churches%20membership&pg=PT33#v=onepage&q=samavesam%20of%20telugu%20baptist%20churches%20membership&f=false }} * {{cite journal | author=T. Punnaiah | title=My Memoir, Ministry and Message | year=2010 | volume= | issue= | isbn= }} * {{cite journal | author=K. J. W. Jayakumar (Compiled) | title=The Lights That Never Quench - Baptist Missionaries | year=2008 | volume= | issue= | isbn= }} * {{cite journal | author=[[Ravela Joseph|R. Joseph]] | title=A History of the Telugu Baptist Churches ([[American Baptist Mission]]) | year=2003 | volume= | issue= | isbn= }} * {{cite journal | author=[[Ravela Joseph|R. Joseph]], [[Suneel Bhanu|B. Suneel Bhanu]] (Compiled) | title=Bibliography of Original Christian Writings in India in Telugu | year=1993 | volume= | issue= | isbn= }} * {{cite journal | author=G. Babu Rao | title=Wisdom Tradition and the Indian Parallels with special reference to Telugu Literature | year=1990 | volume= | issue= | url =http://www.religion-online.org/showarticle.asp?title=3540 }} * {{cite journal | author=American Baptist Historical Society | title=Foundations: A Baptist Journal of History and Theology | year=1968 | volume=11-12 | issue= | isbn= }} {{s-start}} {{s-rel}} {{succession box | before=[[The Reverend|The Rev.]] William Carey,[[Ravela Joseph|R. Joseph]], ''A History of the Telugu Baptist Churches ([[American Baptist Mission]])'', ACTC, Secunderabad, 2003, p.61. [[Samavesam of Telugu Baptist Churches|STBC]]| title=Pastor,
[[Samavesam of Telugu Baptist Churches|STBC]]-Waterbury Memorial
Telugu Baptist Church,
[[Chennai]]|after=[[The Reverend|The Rev.]] K. Joseph, [[Samavesam of Telugu Baptist Churches|STBC]]| years=1951-1957}} {{succession box | before=[[The Reverend|The Rev.]] K. Devadanam''Pastors who served the [[Samavesam of Telugu Baptist Churches|STBC]]-Centenary Baptist Church'' in Souvenir of the 125th Anniversary of the [[Samavesam of Telugu Baptist Churches]]-Centenary Baptist Church, Secunderabad, 2000. [[Samavesam of Telugu Baptist Churches|STBC]]| title=Pastor,
[[Samavesam of Telugu Baptist Churches|STBC]]-[[Centenary Baptist Church]],
[[Secunderabad]]|after=[[The Reverend|The Rev.]] N. Thomas, [[Samavesam of Telugu Baptist Churches|STBC]]| years=1977 - 1986}} {{s-hon}} {{succession box | before=| title=President,

Wilson]] (Edited), ''The Church on the Move'': Essays in honour of [[Victor Premasagar]]'', Christian Literature Society, Madras, 1988, p.vi. [https://books.google.com/books?ei=iR-HVZnHN43GuAT82IDwBQ&id=S-wrAAAAMAAJ&dq=victor+premasagar+g.babu+rao&focus=searchwithinvolume&q=babu+rao] [[Church of South India|CSI]]| title=[[Teacher]] - in - [[Old Testament]],

Babu Rao, [[CBCNC]]| years=1973 - 1977}} {{s-end}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Solomon, Gaddala}} [[Category:Telugu people]] [[Category:20th-century Christian clergy]] [[Category:Indian Christian theologians]] [[Category:Senate of Serampore College (University) alumni]] [[Category:Senate of Serampore College (University) faculty]] [[Category:Palmer Theological Seminary]] [[Category:Cross-cultural studies]] [[Category:1910 births]] [[Category:1993 deaths]]

revision.comment: added reference to Wisconsin tourism and gemütlichkeit, provided definitions of hygge and gemytlig, edited spelling to match across article
revision.text:
[[File:Gemuetlichkeit.jpg|thumb|A typical German beergarden scene, permeated by Gemütlichkeit]] '''''Gemütlichkeit''''' ({{IPA-de|ɡəˈmyːtlɪçkaɪt|-|De-gemuetlichkeit.ogg}}) is a [[German language|German-language]] word used to convey the idea of a state or feeling of warmth, friendliness,http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/gem%C3%BCtlichkeit and good cheer. Other qualities encompassed by the term include coziness, [[Inner peace|peace of mind]], and a sense of belonging and well-being springing from social acceptance. ==History and etymology== ''Gemütlichkeit'' derives from ''gemütlich'', the adjective of ''Gemüt'', which means "heart, mind, temper, feeling" expressed by (and cognate with) English ''[[:wikt:mood|mood]]''. The [[German language|German]] [[abstract noun]] ''Gemütlichkeit'' has been adopted into English.{{cite book | title = Oxford dictionary of English| author = Soanes, C. and Stevenson, A. (ed.) | year= 2007| publisher = ''[[Oxford University Press]]''}} The current meaning of the word derives from its use in the [[Biedermeier]] period. By the second half of the 19th century, it also became associated with a set of traits supposedly unique to the [[German culture]]. In the United States, the city of [[Jefferson, Wisconsin]] uses the phrase: "''The Gemütlichkeit City''" as its motto.{{cite web|url=http://jeffersonchamberwi.com/ |title=Jefferson Chamber of Commerce | in Jefferson, WI |publisher=Jeffersonchamberwi.com |date= |accessdate=2013-09-10}} The Wisconsin Department of Tourism also offers their own definition of gemütlichkeit on travelwisconsin.com, with claims that gemütlichkeit is a feeling one gets when visiting Wisconsin.{{cite web |url=https://www.travelwisconsin.com/gemutlichkeit |website=Travel Wisconsin |accessdate=13 October 2018}} The word can be used in descriptions of holidays.{{cite web | url = http://www.nysun.com/pf.php?id=5615&v=3325025911 | title = Recent Fiction | author = Benjamin Lytal | date= 2004-12-01 | publisher = ''[[The New York Sun]]'' | quote = [[Nella Bielski|Ms. Bielski]]'s novel [''The Year is '42''] is quite good, a quick read that seems in sync with holiday '''''Gemutlichkeit''''' and holiday sadness. | accessdate = 2007-11-16}}
* [http://en.pons.eu/german-english/Gem%C3%BCtlichkeit Gemütlichkeit] PONS Online-Dictionary In the 1973 [[English contract law]] case ''[[Jarvis v Swans Tours Ltd]]'', a holidaymaker sued after not receiving the ''Gemütlichkeit'' promised by the promotional literature for a [[package holiday]] to the Swiss Alps. The [[community|communal]] connotations of ''Gemütlichkeit'' are also emphasized in some uses of the term. For example, one academic described it as a tradition of "public festivity" (in the form of a "mixture of music, food, and drink"), which "promote[d] community solidarity."{{cite web | url = http://www.allacademic.com/meta/p105731_index.html | title = Paper presented at the annual meeting of the American Studies Association | author = John Fairfield | date= 2006-10-05 | accessdate = 2007-11-16 | authorlink = John Fairfield (academic)}} The [[Harlem Renaissance]] was then cited as of how a sense of ''Gemütlichkeit'' arises from a "mix of music, art and politics in service of community consciousness". ''Gemütlichkeit'' has been appropriated at least once to describe the tenor of an economic era rather than spirit of a social gathering. In analyzing the "inflation dampening effects of [[globalization]]" a [[Georgia Southern University]] professor wrote that certain U.S. economic trends could "spell an end of the Gemütlichkeit — a situation in which cheap labor and money abroad as well as ever-increasing productivity at home had permitted an uninterrupted spell of controlled growth in overall prices".{{cite web | url = http://savannahnow.com/node/301323 | title = Rising costs of necessities signal an end of ''Gemütlichkeit''| author = [[Michael Reksulak]] | date= 2007-06-09 | publisher = ''[[Savannah Morning News]]'' | accessdate = 2007-11-16}} ==Similar words in other languages== [[English language|English]] has no direct translation for ''gemütlich'' or ''Gemütlichkeit''. ''Cozy'' captures an element of it but crucially lacks those of friendliness and belonging. Stemming from the [[Scottish Gaelic]] word ''còsagach'', cozy means "1 Full of holes or crevices. 2 Snug, warm, cosy, sheltered. 3 Spongy", according to [[Edward Dwelly]]'s Scots Gaelic - English dictionary.{{cite web|url=http://www.cairnwater.co.uk/gaelicdictionary/index.aspx?Language=en |title=Dwelly's great Scots Gaelic - English dictionary|publisher= Dwelly's great Scots Gaelic - English dictionary, online version |year=1911|accessdate=2014-02-07}} The English author [[G. K. Chesterton]] mentioned ''Gemütlichkeit'' in his 1906 book on ''Charles Dickens''. In the first half of the seventh chapter on "English comfort" he wrote that "... the thing you cannot see out of Germany is a German beer-garden", a venue which is the very epitome of ''Gemütlichkeit'' in that nation. Later, seeking to define what he regarded as a peculiarly English quality captured in the chapter title ''English comfort'', he continued, "The word ''comfort'' is not indeed the right word, it conveys too much of the slander of mere sense; the true word is ''cosiness'', a word not translatable."{{cite web|url=http://www.cse.dmu.ac.uk/~mward/gkc/books/CD-2.txt|author=Gilbert Keith Chesterton|title=Charles Dickens|year=1906|accessdate=2014-02-07}} Indeed, it is no direct synonym for ''Gemütlichkeit''. The [[Swedish language]] equivalent is ''gemytlig'', deriving directly from the German word and sharing its meaning.{{anchor|Hygge}} The [[Danish language|Danish]] also has ''gemytlig''https://ordnet.dk/ddo/ordbog?query=gemytlig {{IPA-da|geˈmydli|}} but uses ''[[Culture of Denmark#Hygge|hygge]]'' {{IPA-da|ˈhyɡə|}} (hyggelig as an adjective) instead.{{cite web|url=http://iowapublicradio.org/post/enjoying-winter-danish-concept-hygge|title=Enjoying Winter with the Danish Concept of "Hygge"|publisher= [[Iowa Public Radio]] |date =2014-01-13 |accessdate=2014-02-07}} Likewise, in [[Norwegian language|Norwegian]] the word translates into "hyggelig", but the meaning is closer to the word "[[wikt:koselig|koselig]]" which means cozy, comfortable, nice, or pleasant. The [[Dutch language|Dutch]] equivalent "[[gezelligheid]]" has broader social connotations than the German ''Gemütlichkeit'' and can be more accurately compared to the Danish "hygge". In [[Bulgarian language|Bulgarian]], the word is commonly translated as ''уют'' {{IPA-mk|oˈjut|}} and {{IPA-ru|ʊˈjut|}} in [[Russian language|Russian]], which means cosiness, comfort, contentment, ease, and carries almost identical connotations as the German word. The [[Romance languages]] with Latin roots do not have a single term expressing the many connotations of ''Gemütlichkeit''. ==See also== *[[Quality time]] ==References== {{reflist|2}} ==External links== {{wiktionary|Gemütlichkeit}} * {{wiktionary-inline}} * [https://blog.beamspace.com/index.php/2016/07/14/top-5-reasons-to-organize-your-home/ Top 5 Reasons to Organize Your Home] {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Gemütlichkeit}} [[Category: Sociological terminology]] [[Category:German words and phrases]] [[Category:Words and phrases with no direct English translation]]

[[File:Green's Dictionary of Slang cover.png|thumb|Cover of the first volume of the print edition (2010) of ''Green's Dictionary of Slang''.]] '''''Green's Dictionary of Slang''''' (''GDoS'') is a multivolume [[dictionary]] defining and giving the history of [[English language|English]] [[slang]] from around the [[Early Modern English]] period to the present day written by [[Jonathon Green]]. As a [[historical dictionary]] it covers not only slang words in use in the present day but also those from the past which are no longer used, and illustrates its definitions with quotations. It is thus comparable in method to the ''[[Oxford English Dictionary]]'' (''OED'') though with a narrower scope, since it includes only slang words; nonetheless it is more comprehensive within its scope, containing 125,000 items of slang while the ''OED'' has only 7,700 terms carrying a slang label.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.tbray.org/ongoing/When/201x/2013/08/02/Oxford-English-Dictionary|title=ongoing by Tim Bray · The Oxford English Dictionary|website=www.tbray.org|language=en|access-date=2017-10-10}}</ref>
== History == Jonathon Green, the dictionary's author, considers the work to be in the lineage of English slang dictionaries going back to [[Francis Grose|Francis Grose's]] 18th-century [[A Classical Dictionary of the Vulgar Tongue|''Classical Dictionary of the Vulgar Tongue'']] and further to the 1566 glossary ''[[A Caveat or Warning for Common Cursitors|Caveat for Common Cursetours]]'' by Thomas Harman.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=https://greensdictofslang.com/about/print/introduction|title=Introduction (print edition) — Green’s Dictionary of Slang|website=greensdictofslang.com|language=en|access-date=2017-10-10}}</ref> The dictionary's direct ancestor is [[Eric Partridge|Eric Partridge's]] ''[[A Dictionary of Slang and Unconventional English|Dictionary of Slang and Unconventional English]]'' (1937–84) which originally inspired Green to write his own dictionary of slang, published as ''The Dictionary of Contemporary Slang'' in 1984.<ref name=":1">{{Cite journal|last=Green|first=Jonathon|last2=Kendal|first2=David P.|date=2017|title=Writing and Publishing ''Green's Dictionary of Slang''|url=http://muse.jhu.edu/article/671962|journal=Dictionaries: Journal of the Dictionary Society of North America|volume=38|issue=1|pages=82–95|via=Project MUSE}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|title=The Dictionary of Contemporary Slang|last=Green|first=Jonathon|publisher=Pan Books|year=1984|isbn=|location=London|pages=}}</ref>
In 1993 [[Cassell (publisher)|Cassell]] commissioned Green to create a new dictionary, this time broadening the focus to include slang terms from approximately 1500 onwards, but without citations. The first edition of the single-volume ''Cassell's Dictionary of Slang'' appeared in 1998.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Cassell's Dictionary of Slang|last=Green|first=Jonathon|publisher=Cassell|year=1998|isbn=|location=London|pages=}}</ref> Cassell immediately commissioned a sequel with full historical quotations as in the ''OED''. Green turned down an offer from Routledge to revise Partridge's dictionary in order to embark on his own work of far greater magnitude, helped by the bequest of his deceased uncle which allowed Green to spend much more money on the necessary lexicographical research than his publisher was able to provide.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" />
Work on the dictionary continued throughout the 2000s, with a second edition of ''Cassell's Dictionary of Slang'' appearing as an interim work in 2005<ref>{{Cite book|title=Cassell's Dictionary of Slang|last=Green|first=Jonathon|publisher=Cassell|year=2005|isbn=|edition=2nd|location=London|pages=}}</ref> and, after the acquisition of Cassell by [[Chambers Harrap|Chambers]], a third edition under the new title of the ''Chambers Slang Dictionary'' in 2008.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Chambers Slang Dictionary|last=Green|first=Jonathon|publisher=Chambers|year=2008|isbn=|location=Edinburgh|pages=}}</ref>
In 2009 the dictionary was ready to be published in its first edition,<ref name=":1" /> and was released in 2010 in Great Britain by [[Hachette (publisher)|Hachette]] (the new owners of Chambers Harrap) and in 2011 in North America by the [[Oxford University Press]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://greensdictofslang.com/about/introduction|title=Introduction to the Digital Edition — Green’s Dictionary of Slang|website=greensdictofslang.com|language=en|access-date=2017-11-06}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|title=Green's Dictionary of Slang|last=Green|first=Jonathon|publisher=Chambers|year=2010|isbn=0550104402|location=London|pages=}}</ref> Though Green hoped to release a full and regularly updated online edition shortly thereafter,<ref name=":0" /> due to a legal dispute with the dictionary's new publishers, only a limited release as an [[Oxford Reference]] ebook was possible, with no updates made.<ref name=":1" />
However, having found a suitable partner through an appeal posted on the website ''[[Language Log]]'', an updated and fully searchable online edition of the dictionary was launched in 2016 as an independent publication.<ref name=":1" /><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://blog.greensdictofslang.com/news/2016/welcome-to-gdos-online|title=GDoS News — Welcome to GDoS Online|website=blog.greensdictofslang.com|access-date=2017-11-06}}</ref>
== Reception == Upon release of the first print edition, critical reception was broadly positive. ''[[The Guardian]]'',<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/books/2010/dec/18/dictionary-slang-guardian-style-review|title=Green's Dictionary of Slang by Jonathon Green and Guardian Style by David Marsh & Amelia Hodsdon – review|last=Poole|first=Steven|date=2010-12-18|work=The Guardian|access-date=2017-10-11|language=en-GB|issn=0261-3077}}</ref> the ''[[Financial Times]]'',<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.ft.com/content/81c14682-0ee5-11e0-9ec3-00144feabdc0|title=Old slang’s time|last=Hitchings|first=Henry|date=2010|work=Financial Times|access-date=6 November 2017|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref> ''[[The Daily Telegraph]]'',<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/books/referenceandanthologybooksrevie/8081704/Dictionary-of-slang-Everything-went-off-A1-he-said.html|title=Dictionary of slang: 'Everything went off A1, he said’|last=Noel-Tod|first=Jeremy|date=2010-10-25|access-date=2017-11-06|language=en-GB|issn=0307-1235}}</ref> the ''[[New Statesman]]'',<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.newstatesman.com/books/2011/01/green-dictionary-slang-century|title=Green's Dictionary of Slang|website=www.newstatesman.com|language=en|access-date=2017-11-06}}</ref> and ''[[The New York Times]]''<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/04/03/books/review/slanguage-books-review.html|title=Slanguage - Books - Review|last=Zimmer|first=Ben|date=2011-04-01|work=The New York Times|access-date=2017-10-11|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}}</ref> among others praised the dictionary for its breadth and the quality of the research. It received the 2012 [[Dartmouth Medal]] of the [[American Library Association]] as a reference work of outstanding quality and significance.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.ala.org/awardsgrants/content/greens-dictionary-slang|title=Green's Dictionary of Slang {{!}} Awards & Grants|website=www.ala.org|language=en|access-date=2017-11-06}}</ref> [[Michael Quinion]] of the website ''World Wide Words'' wrote of the dictionary's approach that "In its historical approach, GDoS matches the ''Oxford English Dictionary'' and it’s not hyperbolic to suggest that it’s the OED of slang."<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.worldwidewords.org/reviews/re-gre1.htm|title=World Wide Words: Green’s Dictionary of Slang|website=World Wide Words|language=en-gb|access-date=2017-11-06}}</ref>
Academic reviews of the print edition also generally praised the dictionary,<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Coleman|first=Julie|date=March 2012|title=Jonathon Green, ''Green's dictionary of slang''. Edinburgh: Chambers, 2010, 3 vols. pp. xxxi + 6085. ISBN 9-7805-5010-4403. £295.00.|url=https://www.cambridge.org/core/journals/english-language-and-linguistics/article/green-jonathon-greens-dictionary-of-slang-edinburgh-chambers-2010-3-vols-pp-xxxi-6085-isbn-9780550104403-29500/516371B1EB22148D27291326310A66BD|journal=[[English Language and Linguistics]]|volume=16|issue=1|pages=193–9|via=}}</ref> though there were some points of criticism. Michael Adams wrote in the journal ''Dictionaries'' that, though the dictionary was good overall, there were problems with the clarity and focus of definitions and the accuracy of etymology which he felt left him unable to unequivocally recommend ''GDoS'' to the exclusion of previous similar dictionaries (such as the ''[[Historical Dictionary of American Slang]]'' (''HDAS'') of Jonathan Lighter) as others had done.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Adams|first=Michael|date=2012|title=''Green's Dictionary of Slang'' (review)|url=https://muse.jhu.edu/article/495814|journal=Dictionaries: Journal of the Dictionary Society of North America|volume=33|pages=208–244|via=Project MUSE}}</ref>
A similar comparison to ''HDAS'' was made by [[Simon Winchester]] in the ''[[The New York Review of Books|New York Review of Books]]''.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.nybooks.com/articles/2012/03/08/mongrel-speech-streets/|title=The Mongrel Speech of the Streets|last=Winchester|first=Simon|date=2012-03-08|work=The New York Review of Books|access-date=2017-10-11|issn=0028-7504}}</ref> Unlike Adams, Winchester wrote that ''GDoS'' scored strongly against ''HDAS'' in almost every regard, but his view was disputed in a response by [[Geoffrey Nunberg]] of ''[[Language Log]]'', who claimed that Lighter's dictionary was better organized and often had earlier citations which ''GDoS'' missed.<ref name=":2">{{Cite web|url=http://languagelog.ldc.upenn.edu/nll/?p=3847|title=Language Log » Winchester on Green and Lighter in NYRB|website=languagelog.ldc.upenn.edu|access-date=2017-10-11}}</ref> Green responded to Nunberg pointing out that ''HDAS'' often used a hypothetical date of composition of texts in its citations where ''GDoS'' consistently uses the more certain, but inevitably later date of first publication instead, and also defending ''GDoS'' against some of Nunberg's other claims.<ref name=":2" />
Upon launch of the online edition in 2016, the new version also garnered praise in the ''[[International Journal of Lexicography]]''<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Hanks|first=Patrick|date=8 February 2017|title=Jonathon Green. 2016. ''Green’s Dictionary of Slang''|url=https://academic.oup.com/ijl/article-abstract/doi/10.1093/ijl/ecx001/2975609?redirectedFrom=fulltext|journal=[[International Journal of Lexicography]]|volume=|pages=ecx001|via=}}</ref> and positive news coverage in publications including ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'',<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://time.com/4532321/slang-dictionary-greens-online/|title=Green's, the Biggest Slang Dictionary Ever, Just Went Online|website=Time|access-date=2017-11-06}}</ref> [[Quartz (publication)|''Qz.com'']],<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://qz.com/805633/greens-dictionary-of-slang-jonathon-green-has-spent-35-years-compiling-entries-for-a-132000-word-online-slang-dictionary-that-you-can-search-for-free/|title=This man has spent 35 years on a 132,000-word slang dictionary that you can search online for free|last=Cooper|first=Marta|work=Quartz|access-date=2017-11-06|language=en-US}}</ref> and ''[[Slate (magazine)|Slate]]''.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.slate.com/blogs/lexicon_valley/2016/10/13/jonathon_green_explains_how_he_brought_his_slang_dictionary_to_the_internet.html|title=Green’s Dictionary of Slang Comes Online|last=Green|first=Jonathon|date=2016-10-13|work=Slate|access-date=2017-11-06|language=en-US|issn=1091-2339}}</ref>
== References == <references />

[[File:The Bit o' Writin'.jpg|thumb|right|200px|1865 cover of ''The Bit o' Writin''.]] This is a [[bibliography]] of the works of [[John Banim]] and [[Michael Banim]].<ref>The Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature, Volume 1, By Frederick Wilse Bateson, Revised by Michael Sadleir, Cambridge University Press, 1969.</ref> Many of their works were published pseudonymously under the name "The O'Hara Family". John used the name Barnes O'Hara, while Michael used the name Abel O'Hara.<ref name="Oxford">Oxford Dictionary of National Biography, Vol 3, pgs 668-670, Oxford University Press, 2004.</ref>
==Fiction== *''Tales by the O'Hara Family'', First Series, 1825. **''Crohoore of the Billhook'' by Michael Banim. **''The Fetches'' by John Banim. **''John Doe'' by John and Michael Banim. *''Tales by the O'Hara Family'', Second Series, 1826. **''The Nowlans'' by John Banim. **''Peter of the Castle'' by John and Michael Banim. *''The Boyne Water'' by John Banim, 1826. *''The Anglo-Irish of the Nineteenth Century'' by John Banim, (published anonymously), 1828. *''The Croppy: A Tale of 1798'' by Michael Banim, 1828. *''The Denounced'' by John Banim, 1830. *''The Smuggler'' by John Banim, 1831. *''The Ghost-Hunter and His Family'' by Michael Banim, 1833. *''The Mayor of Windgap'' by Michael Banim, 1835. *''The Bit o' Writin'' (stories) by John and Michael Banim, 1838.<ref>According to Michael Banim in his introduction to ''The Bit o' Writin'', (James Duffy and Co, Dublin, 1865), the two stories ''The Bit o' Writin'' and ''The Hare Hound and the Witch'' were written by him (Michael Banim) and the rest of the stories were written by John Banim.</ref> **''The Bit o' Writin'' **''The Irish Lord Lieutenant and His Double'' **''The Family of the Cold Feet'' **''The Hare-Hound and the Witch'' **''The Soldier's Billet'' **''A Peasant Girl's Love'' **''The Hall of the Castle'' **''The Half-Brothers'' **''Twice Lost, But Saved'' **''The Faithful Servant'' **''The Roman Merchant'' **''Ill Got, Ill Gone'' **''The Church-Yard Watch'' **''The Last of the Storm'' **''The Rival Dreamers'' **''The Substitute'' **''The White Bristol'' **''The Stolen Sheep'' **''The Publican's Dream'' **''The Ace of Clubs'' *''Father Connell'' by John and Michael Banim, 1842. *''Clough Fion'' by Michael Banim, 1852. *''The Town of the Cascades'' by Michael Banim, 1864.
==Drama, essays and poetry== *''The Celt's Paradise, in Four Duans'' (poem) by John Banim, 1821. *''Damon and Pythias'' (play) by John Banim, 1821. *''Revelations of the Dead Alive'' by John Banim, (essays, published anonymously), 1824. *''Chaunt of the Cholera: Songs for Ireland'' by John and Michael Banim, 1831.
==External links== * [https://archive.org/search.php?query=banim The Works of John and Michael Banim from Archive.org]
==Sources== {{Reflist}}

{{infobox Museum |name = Legion of Honor |image = Legion of Honor at night.jpg |established = |map_type = United States San Francisco#California#USA |map_size = 220px |location = 100 34th Avenue, [[San Francisco]], [[California]], United States of America |visitors = 177,608 (2010) <ref name=AN>{{cite web|url=http://www.theartnewspaper.com/attfig/attfig10.pdf|title=Exhibition and museum attendance figures 2010|publisher=[[The Art Newspaper]]|location=London|date=April 2011|accessdate=11 April 2011}}</ref> |type = Art museum |director = |publictransit = [[San Francisco Municipal Railway]] |website = http://legionofhonor.famsf.org/ |coordinates = {{Coord|37|47|02|N|122|30|04|W|format=dms|display=inline,title|type:landmark_region:US-CA}} }} '''The Legion of Honor''' (formerly known as '''The California Palace of the Legion of Honor''') is a part of the [[Fine Arts Museums of San Francisco]]<ref>{{cite web|title=Fine Arts Museums San Francisco|url=http://legionofhonor.famsf.org/about/about-fine-arts-museums-san-francisco|work=legionofhonor.famsf.org}}</ref> (FAMSF). The name is used both for the museum collection and for the building in which it is housed. Since Nov 1, 2018, [[Thomas_P._Campbell|Thomas P. Campbell]] serves as its Director and CEO.
==History== [[File:Solar corona above statue of El Cid SF CA.jpg|thumb|Statue of ''[[El Cid]]'' silhouetted by a [[solar corona]] in front of the Legion.]]
The Legion of Honor was the gift of [[Alma de Bretteville Spreckels]], wife of the [[sugar]] magnate and [[thoroughbred]] [[horse racing|racehorse]] owner/breeder [[Adolph B. Spreckels]].<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.artpoint.org/about/index.html | title=About ArtPoint | accessdate=2008-12-12 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080625002625/http://www.artpoint.org/about/index.html <!-- Bot retrieved archive --> |archivedate = 2008-06-25}}</ref> The building is a full-scale replica, by George Applegarth and H. Guillaume, of the French Pavilion at the 1915 [[Panama–Pacific International Exposition]], which in turn was a three-quarter-scale version of the [[Palais de la Légion d'Honneur]] also known as the [[Hôtel de Salm]] in [[Paris]], by Pierre Rousseau (1782). At the close of the exposition, which was located just a few miles away, the [[French government]] granted Spreckels permission to construct a permanent replica of the French Pavilion, but [[World War I]] delayed the groundbreaking until 1921.<ref>{{cite web|url= https://legionofhonor.famsf.org/about/history-legion-honor|title=History of California Palace of the Legion of Honor}}</ref>
The museum building occupies an elevated site in [[Lincoln Park (San Francisco)|Lincoln Park]] in the northwest of the city, with views over the [[Golden Gate Bridge]]. Most of the surrounding Lincoln Park Golf Course is on the site of a [[potter's field]] called the "Golden Gate Cemetery" that the City had bought in 1867. The cemetery was closed in 1908 and the bodies were relocated to [[Colma, California|Colma]]. During seismic retrofitting in the 1990s, however, coffins and skeletal remains were unearthed.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/e/a/1995/01/19/NEWS8767.dtl |title = Remains of S.F. pioneers are laid to new, final rest |accessdate= 2007-02-08 |last= Sullivan |first= Kathleen |date= 1995-01-19 |publisher= San Francisco Examiner }}</ref>
"Between March 1992 and November 1995—its seventy-first anniversary—the Legion underwent a major renovation that included seismic strengthening, building systems upgrades, restoration of historic architectural features, and an underground expansion that added 35,000 square feet. Visitor services and program facilities increased, without altering the historic façade or adversely affecting the environmental integrity of the site. The architects chosen to accomplish this challenging feat were [[Edward Larrabee Barnes]] and [[Mark Cavagnero]]."<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://legionofhonor.famsf.org/about/history-legion-honor|title=History of the Legion of Honor|date=2011-06-28|work=Legion of Honor|access-date=2017-09-08|language=en}}</ref>
The plaza and fountain in front of the Palace of the Legion of Honor is the western terminus of the [[Lincoln Highway]], the first improved road for automobiles across [[United States|America]]. The terminus marker and an interpretive plaque are located in the southwest corner of the plaza and fountain, just to the left of the Palace. Dominating the classical plaza is "Pax Jerusalemme," a modern sculpture by [[Mark di Suvero]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.sfgate.com/entertainment/article/A-Legion-of-Concerns-Over-Sculpture-Di-Suvero-s-2713466.php|publisher=San Francisco Chronicle | title =A Legion of Concerns Over Sculpture / Di Suvero's mediocre `Pax Jerusalem' may signal a troubling trend at Fine Arts Museums}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Robinson|first1=Walter|title=San Francisco Sketchy|url=http://www.artnet.com/magazineus/reviews/robinson/the-legion-of-honor3-30-10.asp|website=www.artnet.com}}</ref>
==Collections== The Legion of Honor displays a collection spanning more than 6,000 years of ancient and European art and houses the Achenbach Foundation for Graphic Arts in a neoclassical building overlooking Lincoln Park and the Golden Gate Bridge.
===European Art=== [[File:Bretteville Spreckels Gallery, Legion of Honor.jpg|thumb|upright|The [[Adolph B. Spreckels|Adolph B.]] and [[Alma de Bretteville Spreckels]] Gallery showcasing sculptures of [[Auguste Rodin]]]] The museum contains a representative collection of European art, the largest portion of which is French. Its most distinguished collection is of [[sculpture]] by [[Auguste Rodin]]. Casts of some of his most famous works are on display, including one of ''[[The Thinker]]'' in the Court of Honor. However, there are individual works by many other artists, including [[François Boucher]], [[Rembrandt Harmenszoon van Rijn|Rembrandt]], [[Thomas Gainsborough|Gainsborough]], [[Jacques-Louis David|David]], [[El Greco]], [[Giambattista Pittoni]], [[Peter Paul Rubens|Rubens]], and many of the [[Impressionism|Impressionists]] and [[post-Impressionism|post-Impressionists]]—[[Edgar Degas|Degas]], [[Pierre-Auguste Renoir|Renoir]], [[Monet]], [[Camille Pissarro|Pissarro]], [[Georges Seurat|Seurat]], [[Cézanne]] and others. There are also representative works by key 20th century figures such as [[Braque]] and [[Picasso]], and works of contemporary artists like [[Gottfried Helnwein]] and [[Robert Crumb]].
The museum's contemporary art initiative brings the work of living artists into dialogue with the buildings and collections of the [[De Young (museum)|de Young Museum]] and Legion of Honor, with exhibitions such as [[Urs Fischer]] and [[Sarah Lucas]] in juxtaposition with the museum's acclaimed Rodin collection to commemorate the centenary of Rodin's death in 1917.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.juxtapoz.com/news/installation/urs-fischer-takes-over-the-legion-of-honor/|title=Urs Fischer takes over the Legion of Honor|last=|first=|date=April 22, 2017|work=Juxtapoz|access-date=June 26, 2017|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref>
[[File:Monet Grand Canal Legion of Honor.jpg|thumb|''The Grand Canal, Venice'', 1908 by [[Claude Monet]].]] ===Collection highlights=== * ''[[Icon of Saints John the Baptist and Minias (Bicci di Lorenzo)|Icon of Saints John the Baptist and Minias]]'', and ''[[Saint Anthony and Saint Stephen Icons]]'', [[Bicci di Lorenzo]] (15th century) * ''[[St. Francis Venerating the Crucifix]]'', [[El Greco]], 1595 * ''[[St. John the Baptist]]'', El Greco, 1600 * ''[[The Tribute Money (Rubens)|The Tribute Money]]'', [[Peter Paul Rubens|Rubens]], 1612 * ''Descent from the Cross'', [[Giambattista Pittoni]], 1750 * ''[[The Age of Bronze]]'', [[Auguste Rodin]], 1875 * ''[[Trotting Horse]]'' [[Edgar Degas]], 1881 * ''[[The Kiss (Rodin sculpture)|The Kiss]]'', Auguste Rodin, 1884 * ''[[The Grand Canal (Monet)|The Grand Canal]]'', [[Claude Monet]], 1908 * ''[[Water Lilies (Monet series)|Water lilies]]'', Claude Monet, 1914
==Symphonic organ== {{Main|Spreckels Organ}} [[File:Organ at California Palace of the Legion Of Honor.jpg|thumb|left|The [[symphonic organ]].]]
In 1924, [[John D. Spreckels]] commissioned the Ernest M. Skinner Company of Boston to build the [[symphonic organ]]. The museum organ, which is housed inside the museum above the main galleries, has 4 manuals and pedals, 7 divisions, 63 ranks, with a total of 4,526 pipes. Symphonic music is especially effective on the museum organ with its battery of pneumatically operated percussion instruments and set of tubular chimes. A thunder pedal is used for the musical representation of storms. All together, the organ comprises one Great Organ, a Swell Organ, a Choir Organ featuring a 16-foot Contra Dulciana, Choir Organ Echo, a Solo Organ, Solo Organ Echo, an Arch Organ outfitted with 8-foot Arch Clarion, a 64-foot [[Gravissima]] and a 32-foot Bourdon Profunda, in addition to the final Traps that were enclosed in the Choir: Bass drum, castanets, Chinese block, crash cymbal, gong snare drum (f), snare drum (ff), and a tambourine triangle. {{Clear}}
==Gallery== <gallery widths=200 heights=200> File:Rodin's The Thinker.jpg|Statue of ''[[The Thinker]]'' by [[Auguste Rodin]] in the front of the museum. File:Table, Andre-Charles Boulle, Paris, c. 1670-1680, marquetry of various woods, pewter, brass, copper, horn, tortoiseshell - California Palace of the Legion of Honor - DSC07731.JPG|[[Andre-Charles Boulle]], [[Boulle Work]] Table c. 1670-1680. File:Fountain Legion of Honor.JPG| Fountain in the front. File:El Cid by Anna Hyatt Huntington in front of Legion of Honor, San Francisco.jpg|[[Equestrian statue]] in front is ''[[El Cid]]'' by [[Anna Hyatt Huntington]]. File:Jeanne d'Arc Joan of Arc at San Francisco's Palace of the Legion of Honor and crepuscular rays.jpg|''[[Joan of Arc]]'' on horseback. File:Binns - Aesthetic teapot CPLH 2004.113a-b.JPG|Female side of Aesthetic teapot designed by R. W. Binns and modeled by James Hadley, 1881. File:17th century Oak Table (Italy) & World Globes (Netherlands).JPG|17th century Oak Table (Italy) and World Globes (Netherlands) </gallery>
==Film appearances== *The Palace is seen in the [[Alfred Hitchcock]] movie ''[[Vertigo (film)|Vertigo]]'' (1958) when Scottie follows Madeleine Elster to the museum, where she stares at one painting for a considerable time. This painting, dubbed ''Beautiful Carlotta'', was a prop created specifically for the production and is not housed at the museum. *The Palace appears in the 1993 miniseries, ''[[Tales of the City (1993 miniseries)|Tales of the City]]'', based on the first of the ''[[Tales of the City]]'' series of novels by [[Armistead Maupin]]. The character of Mary Ann Singleton (played by [[Laura Linney]]) arranges to meet her neighbor Norman Neal Williams (played by [[Stanley DeSantis]]) at the museum, where he meets his fate. *The character Dr. Crippen in the spoof ''[[The Maltese Falcon (1941 film)|Maltese Falcon]]'' sequel ''[[The Black Bird]]'' has an office in the Palace.
==See also== {{Portal|San Francisco Bay Area}} *[[49-Mile Scenic Drive]] *[[De Young Museum]] *[[Holocaust Memorial at California Palace of the Legion of Honor|Holocaust Memorial]]

Also the sources used are all over five years old, some approaching fifteen years and thus some information (mainly regarding the aforementioned categories) could be outdated due to shifts within some of these parties. This article needs major work, or possibly deleting.|date=December 2017}} This is a list of European [[political parties]] that have been classified as [[left-wing politics|left-wing]] or [[far-left politics|far-left]] in the [[political spectrum]].
